author: E M
text:
Trained elephants of the Wayanad Wildlife Sanctuary patrolling the Thottamoola area under the Muthanga range of forests on Friday.— Photo: Special Arrangement

This is the time of the year when wildlife, especially elephants and gaurs, from adjacent sanctuaries reach the Wayanad Wildlife Sanctuary in Kerala in search of fodder and water as part of their annual migration.

It is also the time when there is a rise in incidents of human-wildlife conflict, as wild animals enter human habitats located on the fringes of forests in search of fodder.

However, this time the conflict may be subdued, largely owing to night patrolling by ‘Kumki’ (trained elephants), launched by the Forest and Wildlife Department in human settlements on the fringes of the sanctuary.

Night patrolling is undertaken by the special elephant squad of the WWS with the assistance of Kunju and Pramugha, two trained elephants at the Muthanga krall. Kunju is a tusker and Pramugha a makhana elephant brought from Karnataka recently.

“We started the elephant patrolling in the Thottamoola and Valamvayal areas in the Muthanga range of forests four days ago and it was a huge success,” warden P. Dhaneshkumar said.

The Kumkis are trained to scare away wild pachyderms into the forest, either by using their trunk or tusks.

“We have constituted two teams for the purpose and they would be deployed in areas where wild animals pose a serious threat to the life and property of people,” Mr. Dhaneshkumar said.

Each group comprises seven to eight members, including a forester, two forest beat officers, two or three anti-poaching tribal watchers and mahouts.

The Wayanad sanctuary is using

a squad of trained elephants to assist in the operation
title: ‘Kumki’ patrols to tackle man-animal conflicts
